title: Perma Bans
body: I really think perma banning someone for toxic language is too severe. You guys should create a perma mute instead so people who arent toxic ingame can still play but cant talk. Perma banning is okay if someone trolls a bunch and does that sort of stuff but toxicicity shouldnt be that way.

replies.body:
They already did try perma-chat. They still find other ways to ruin people's game.
Permabans are not harsh in any way shape or form. Toxic players who have no self-control, lack empathy, or simply enjoy the game at other people's expense, they're the only harsh thing about this game. 

The punishments are for them. Due to the fact they're harsh to the community. If players stop being assholes and play the game for what it is, then they won't endure the consequences of their own actions.

> [{quoted}](name=Zombie Gerbil,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=BXOJJEVZ,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2018-09-19T02:51:43.423+0000)

> The punishments are for them. Due to the fact they're harsh to the community. If players stop being assholes and play the game for what it is, then they won't endure the consequences of their own actions.

Consequences of your actions is when you take a pistol, shoot yourself in the foot and your foot is shot.

Violating an arguable and vaguely defined rule and getting an immeasurably harsh punishment(in comparison to the harm you caused) is not "consequences of your actions". It's an improperly enforced rule.

Irrelevant analogy. 
This is on the subject of in-game activity that is abide by Riot's Service policy and the consequences of going against that policy, not the consequences of outside physical harm as you described. It's the choices you make and act on it. Regardless of what the action is. If one chooses to go against the policy, then they acted against it and now faces the consequences of that choice and that action.

Riot gave every individual a choice to read the policy before they joined this game.
Regardless if they read it or not, they agreed to the terms. Regardless they want to abide by the terms, the rules will stand and will be enforced. So if the individual chooses to go against those terms, then Riot will go by the policy accordingly and do what they warned them of.

The rules weren't harsh enough for them to click the "Agreed" button even when they had a choice of saying no and playing a different game.

> [{quoted}](name=Zombie Gerbil,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=BXOJJEVZ,comment-id=000200000000,timestamp=2018-09-19T06:42:46.588+0000)

It's the choices you make and act on it. Regardless of what the action is. If one chooses to go against the policy, then they acted against it and now faces the consequences of that choice and that action.

Yes, but those are not direct consequences anymore, as you try to imply repeatedly - there is proxy who passes the sentence an swings the sword.

And while I can't say the rule is unreasonable(for the most part), the sentence is too primitive and unusually brutal to put as much faith in it as you do.

They are the consequences, regardless if someone personally agrees with it or not. They agreed to the terms. If the individual chose to play this game, they agreed to the so-called "harsh" punishment policy. Regardless if they read it or not. That policy will stand regardless of any situation and of any circumstances. _My faith in the matter is irrelevant_ and isn't the topic. The subject is that when you agree to something, you abide by it, if you do not agree to it, then don't sign it by agreeing to it and EXPECT the consequences. Naivety and ignorance is a choice by that individual.

The policy isn't a puzzle unless the individual lack common sense as they lack common courtesy that most common individuals have. Any individual can empathize with a situation that occurs and easily remembers that they cannot say or do because the policy says so. It is not Riot's responsibility for a player not to remember the terms they agreed to. Riot isn't liable to any player in any way shape or form. Riot isn't responsible for a player choice or action in the game. Riot is responsible for one thing and that is providing players a friendly, fun, colorful game while enforcing and following their own policy at the best to their ability. Every player has a choice, but every choice can has a consequence. 

Nothing more. Nothing less.
Once again, the punishment wasn't harsh enough for someone not to agree to download and play this game. Otherwise, this game would cease to exist in their hobby.

Despite policy being Riot's decision, it can still be wrong, unacceptable or even outrageous and even Riot can't afford doing some things, no mattter where they are written. For example, you would be totally not okay if company banned women from the game upon identifying that account belongs to one of them.

It would be a bad practice on a big scale, it would hit the news, someone would lose his job or even go to jail, even though Riot is not liable to any player in any way, shape or form.

And while current situation is not as extreme and affects less players, I find the current punishment system unfair and abusive, and I have yet to read why it isn't. It crossed the point where I, not as a victim of it, but as a concerned bystander, am calling it out on being just wrong and hurting people when it could be avoided.

Anything and everything can be wrong. By opinions. That's all this is. Opinions. But at the end of the day, WE ALL agreed to the terms. We pay no subscriptions nor we did we have to pay for the game. The only thing we are expected of is to read and follow the policy. If we're going to go by opinions, I don't believe the punishments are harsh. Me nor does any of my friends have a problem with the penalty or dealing with the penalty. Some of them have gotten a 14-day ban. They learned quickly, especially when I was able to provide some insight, consoling when we play, and discourage them by reminding them of the outcome. My friends and I are all beta players. None of us think the punishments are harsh.

Due to the fact, there are many flags to go through as well as penalty tiers before you hit that permaban. That permaban is extremely hard to obtain unless you oblivious to the policy you agreed to and say something against the zero-tolerance policy, then you're on thin ice. If someone is hit by this ban, then they should immediately research the terms of use or contact Riot Support. Riot Support is normally reasonable to these unfortunates outcome and will lift the ban. You'll lose honor, but at least it's better than losing time you put into the game.

Here's the thing. The system doesn't discriminate. So that example is irrelevant. But no, I would not be okay with a woman being banned, but that isn't the subject here. **The subject is about players who went out of their way and ruined people's games consistently and finally faced the consequences of their actions.** I don't empathize with the players who get struck by the ban. Because they never had any empathy for the players they ruined the game for. The system is far from abusive and unfair due to the regulation of the system. The only thing that is unfair is the players who choose to run it down mid because the jungler didn't gank or gave them blue buff. What's abusive are the players who abuse the chat by ruining someone's experience in the game just because the abused player didn't play by their standards. 

The policy is there for the community who doesn't want to tolerate these players nor do they want anyone else to experience that bad game. The policy is only harsh to those who are there to harm. Harsh to those who are ignorant. Harsh to those who simply do not care about anything but themselves or anyone else's feelings. The majority of the community does not want them here, and Riot doesn't either. Roit sees that and that's why the ban is as severe is it is meant to be.

The zero tolerance system actually does discriminate people of cultures other than yours. While "n%%%%r" is something unacceptable for you and "black" is okay, it's basically vice versa in my country. So yes, being ignorant and not properly educated I might call lucian a "n%%%%%r", get two weeks ban and since this very moment the behaviour you(raised as a proud american not using "slurs") are free to display every game, will get my account permabanned.

The only thing that is unfair is the players who choose to run it down mid because the jungler didn't gank or gave them blue buff. What's abusive are the players who abuse the chat by ruining someone's experience in the game just because the abused player didn't play by their standards. 

Never defended running it down mid, which is as bad as using hacks in my book. But chat-related stuff is way more debatable, as the definition of "ruined game" becomes pretty blurry, just like the standards of something being offensive. They are not concrete enough to get punished by something as concrete and unquestionable as permaban.

> The policy is there for the community who doesn't want to tolerate these players nor do they want anyone else to experience that bad game. The policy is only harsh to those who are there to harm. Harsh to those who are ignorant. Harsh to those who simply do not care about anything but themselves or anyone else's feelings.

This kind of rhetoric can be applied to real life minor offenders, justifying increasing their punishment from minor fees/tickets to 20-year prison sentences or worse. Rare offender speeds or parks in the wrong place out of empathy or caring about anyone but themselves.

Justifying the scale of punishment by the sole fact that the offender is guilty is inherently faulty.

I could care less about real life analogies due to the fact it's irrelevant to the statement at hand.
The main point of this, if someone doesn't like the rules, doesn't want to follow it, don't.
Just don't think you have a voice or saying just because you went against something you agreed to.

Don't stick around thinking the policy isn't going to bend to their standards because of the majority of toxic players want the rules to change, or the minority who doesn't agree with it doesn't think it's fair. The policy was worked around the community's opinion for the past 10 years. Nothing is going to agree, and I am done going in circles with you. You keep bringing up irrelevant subjects and analogies to justify an in-game rule that every player agreed to before they downloaded the game.
